Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experiences for Undergraduates in the Chemistry Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (Chem-SURF) Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site led by Fillmore Freeman at the University of California - Irvine. The research projects supported in this site are in broad areas of chemistry. Undergraduates will be recruited to this site primarily from institutions that lack infrastructure to support undergraduate research, including students from underrepresented groups. The site will support twelve students per summer in a ten week program. A sample of the projects that undergraduates will work on include: (1) the development of density functional theory with Prof. Kieron Burke; (2) the creation of inexpensive DNA array biosensors with Prof. Robert Corn; (3) development of new electronic structure methods with Prof. Filipp Furche; (4) the study of single molecules on solid surfaces with state-of-the-art tunneling microscopies with Prof. Wilson Ho; (5) the design and synthesis of epoxides and aziridines using organocatlaysts with Prof. Elizabeth Jarvo; and (6) the chemical biology and structural enzymology of natural product biosynthesis with Prof. Sheryl Tsai. In addition to conducting research during the summer, the students participating in this program will participate in a number of professional development activities, including ethics training, and participants will also have opportunities for presentation of research at national disciplinary meetings.

Young scientists need exposure to modern research methods and tools as part of their training. This REU site aims to provide research training using state-of-the-art facilities in a broad range of topics in the chemical sciences. Undergraduate researchers participating in this site will have significant, hands-on access to sophisticated research tools. The diverse student cohort participating in research at this site will be well-prepared for graduate school, and eventual employment as part of the country's technical workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eighteen extraordinarily talented sophomore and junior students majoring in the STEM disciplines (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) were selected to participate in the University of California, Irvine (UCI) Chemistry Department National Science Foundation (NSF) active and intensive 10-week summer 2014 Research Experiences for Undergraduates  (REU Chem-SURF) Program. The REU Chem-SURF participants include members from underrepresented groups, from colleges and universities, from community colleges, and from institutions where undergraduate research opportunities are limited or not available.

 

The students are integrated into their respective research groups as coworkers at a level that allows intellectual ownership and tangible results for a research project. The objectives of the UCI REU Chem-SURF Program include expanding the student’s cognizance of ethical and responsible conduct and helping and training students to develop the collaborative skills, communication skills, critical analysis, critical thinking, and experimental techniques in the STEM disciplines and STEM-related disciplines. REU Chem-SURF emphasizes faculty-student interactions and hands on training in a large selection of research projects with world class Faculty Mentors in challenging and exciting cutting-edge transformative research in modern well-equipped research laboratories with state-of-the-art equipment.

 

The REU Chem-SURF participants are informed of career options in academia, government, and industry at the national and international (global) levels.  They are encouraged to attend graduate school in one of the STEM discipline or in a STEM-related discipline because STEM scientists are uniquely qualified to help solve complex science problems, health problems, and societal problems. Interactions with other UCI campus summer research programs and graduate school application preparation will be of value in shared and crossover activities including conferences and symposia. This will lead to building stronger collaborative links on campus and off campus.  These student-student interactions will give the REU students a larger overview of STEM and STEM-related disciplines, which will help them in planning for graduate school and to seek high aspirations for their future careers. The REU Chem-SURF participants are encouraged to disseminate their REU research results at their home institutions, in scientific journals, and at local, national, and regional scientific meetings.

 

Many opportunities for collegial interactions and cultural, recreational, and social activities are available to the REU Chem-SURF participants.
